references: Settings. Since KDDAug is a model-agnostic data augmentation method, it can seamlessly incorporated into any VQA architectures. To validate the generalization of KDDAug, we applied it to multiple different VQA models: UpDn [5], LMH [19], RUBi [11] and CSS+ [18]. All the results are shown in Table 1.

references: Settings. We incorporated the KDDAug into model UpDn [5], LMH [19] and CSS+ [18], and compared them with the SOTA VQA models both on VQA-CP v2 and VQA v2. According to the model framework design, we group them into: 1) Non-DA Methods: UpDn [5], AReg [46], MuRel [10], GRL [25], CF-VQA [41], GGE-DQ [26], D-VQA [54], IntroD [42], CSS+CL [37], and LMH [19]. 2) DA Methods: CVL [1], Unshuffling [49], CSS [16], CSS+ [18], RandImg [50], SSL [58], MUTANT [22], SimpleAug [31], and ECD [33]. All results are reported in Table 2.

references: KDDAug vs. SimpleAug [31] (Q1). To answer Q1, we compared the answers assigned by KDDAug and SimpleAug. Due to different composition strategies for “Yes/No” questions, we firstly removed the “Yes/No” questions from Daugbasicsubscriptsuperscript𝐷basicaugD^{\text{basic}}_{\text{aug}}. We use a pretrained CLIP [44] (denoted as CLIPrankrank{}_{\text{rank}} and more details are left in the appendix.) to rank the quality of all SimpleAug assigned answers. For more comprehensive comparisons, we divided the augmented samples into three subsets according to the ranks: 1) All augmented samples (100%), 2) Top-50% samples (↑↑\uparrow 50%), and 3) Bottom-50% samples (↓↓\downarrow 50%). We compared KDDAug and SimpleAug on these three subsets, and results are in Table 3.

Results for Q1. From Table 3, we can observe: 1) The performance of SimpleAug on three subsets varies significantly, e.g., bottom-50% samples lead to a huge drop in HM (-0.87%). 2) In contrast, KDDAug on different subsets achieves similar decent performance. 3) With the same augmented image-question pairs, KDDAug consistently outperforms the corresponding SimpleAug by a significant margin (over 8% on HM), which proves the robustness of our answers.

references: Influence of Rule-based Initial Answers (Q2). To evaluate the quality of directly automatically assigned answers, we again used CLIPrankrank{}_{\text{rank}} to divide the augmented samples (except “Yes/No” samples) into two parts. The augmented samples with top-δ𝛿\delta% ranks use rule-based initial answers (cf. Eq. (4)) and left samples use question-type bias (cf. Eq. (2)). All results are shown in Table 4.

references: CLIP-based Filtering. One potential weakness for our VQ pair composition strategy is the excessive training samples, which may increase the training times. To achieve a good trade-off between efficiency and effectiveness, we can utilize a pretrained visual-language model CLIP [44] to filter out less-efficient augmented samples. By “less-efficient”, we mean that the improvements provided by these training samples are marginal. This filtering design is based on the observation that people tend to ask questions about salient objects in the image, i.e., the nouns mentioned in questions should appear prominently in the image. Specifically, we firstly use the template “a photo of <<NOUN>>” to generate prompts for each meaningful noun in the question and utilize CLIP to calculate the similarity score between the image and all corresponding prompts. Then, we use the average similarity score over all meaningful nouns to get the relevance score between the question and the image. We sort all composed VQ pairs according to the relevance score and only the α𝛼\alpha% samples with the top highest relevance scores are reserved (See Table 5 for more details about influence of different α𝛼\alpha).

Results for Q3. From the results in Table 5, we have several observations: 1) When more samples are used, the model performs better, which reflects the robustness of generated pseudo answers. 2) Even if a small number of samples are used (e.g., α%=10%percent𝛼percent10\alpha\%=10\%), KDDAug still achieves decent performance, and is better than SimpleAug (60.85% vs. 57.91%). 3) By adjusting the value of α𝛼\alpha, we can easily achieve a trade-off between training efficiency and model performance.

references: Considering that the initial answer ai​n​i​tsuperscript𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑖𝑡a^{init} is more accurate than the p​r​e​di​dt𝑝𝑟𝑒subscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑡𝑖𝑑pred^{t}_{id} e.g., ID teacher’s ID performance is only 63.01% (cf. Table 6), we follow [42] and use ai​n​i​tsuperscript𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑖𝑡a^{init} as ID knowledge, i.e., at=wi​d∗ai​n​i​t+wo​o​d∗p​r​e​do​o​dtsuperscript𝑎𝑡subscript𝑤𝑖𝑑superscript𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑖𝑡subscript𝑤𝑜𝑜𝑑𝑝𝑟𝑒subscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑡𝑜𝑜𝑑a^{t}=w_{id}*a^{init}+w_{ood}*pred^{t}_{ood}.

Effects of Different Teachers (Q4).
To show the effectiveness of multi-teacher KD strategy, we compared three teachers with different ID teacher weight wi​dsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑑w_{id} and OOD teacher weight wo​o​dsubscript𝑤𝑜𝑜𝑑w_{ood}: 1) Averaged Teacher (Simple Avg.): wi​d=wo​o​d=0.5subscript𝑤𝑖𝑑subscript𝑤𝑜𝑜𝑑0.5w_{id}=w_{ood}=0.5. 2) Only ID Teacher (ID-distill.): wi​d=1,wo​o​d=0formulae-sequencesubscript𝑤𝑖𝑑1subscript𝑤𝑜𝑜𝑑0w_{id}=1,w_{ood}=0. 3) Only OOD Teacher (OOD-distill.): wi​d=0,wo​o​d=1formulae-sequencesubscript𝑤𝑖𝑑0subscript𝑤𝑜𝑜𝑑1w_{id}=0,w_{ood}=1. All results are shown in Table 6.

Results for Q4. From Table 6, we have several observations: 1) Learning from all teachers can improve the performance over baseline. 2) Learning from fixed-weight teachers (i.e., single-teacher KD) can’t achieve good performance on both ID and OOD settings simultaneously, e.g., “OOD-distill.” obtains OOD performance gains (+18.66%) while suffering from a signiﬁcant drop on ID performance (-1.98%). 3) In contrast, our dynamic multi-teacher strategy increases OOD performance by 20.50% while ID performance drops slightly by 0.62%, and achieves the best trade-off performance, which proves its effectiveness.

references:
Effects of Augmentation Diversity (Q5).
To explore the effects of more diverse augmentation types, we compared KDDAug and KDDAug+ with Daugbasicsubscriptsuperscript𝐷basicaugD^{\text{basic}}_{\text{aug}} and Daugextrasubscriptsuperscript𝐷extraaugD^{\text{extra}}_{\text{aug}}. For fair comparison, we didn’t use initial answers and removed all paraphrasing samples from Daugbasicsubscriptsuperscript𝐷basicaugD^{\text{basic}}_{\text{aug}} (denoted as Daug−basicsubscriptsuperscript𝐷basicsuperscriptaugD^{\text{basic}}_{\text{aug}^{-}}) since they are a subset of 𝒟e​x​t​r​asubscript𝒟𝑒𝑥𝑡𝑟𝑎\mathcal{D}_{extra}. Meanwhile, we sampled same number of samples of the “Other” cateogry samples with Daug−basicsubscriptsuperscript𝐷basicsuperscriptaugD^{\text{basic}}_{\text{aug}^{-}} from Daugextrasubscriptsuperscript𝐷extraaugD^{\text{extra}}_{\text{aug}}777Daug−basicsubscriptsuperscript𝐷basicsuperscriptaugD^{\text{basic}}_{\text{aug}^{-}} and Daugextrasubscriptsuperscript𝐷extraaugD^{\text{extra}}_{\text{aug}} have same “Yes/No” and “Number” category samples.. We compared them on different size of samples (different α𝛼\alpha values in CLIP-based filtering). Results are shown in Table 7.

In this section, we add additional experimental results to demonstrate the effects of augmentation diversity. As shown in Table 8, diversity indeed helps model performance (both w/ and w/o initial answers.). However, when using the extra paraphrasing [31], the improvement gains brought by diversity in the smaller size KDDAug+‡ is overwhelmed. Moreover, we only use KDDAug for SOTA comparison rather than KDDAug+ for two reasons: 1) The sample size of whole Daugextrasuperscriptsubscript𝐷augextraD_{\text{aug}}^{\text{extra}} is enormous. Thus, it is infeasible to directly train models with whole Daugextrasuperscriptsubscript𝐷augextraD_{\text{aug}}^{\text{extra}} (KDDAug+). 2) For efficiency and fair comparison with prior work SimpleAug [31], we controlled the number of samples to be the same as SimpleAug (i.e., KDDAug+‡ in Table 7 and 8).

As shown in Table 8, diversity indeed helps model performance (both w/ and w/o initial answers.). However, when using the extra paraphrasing [31], the improvement gains brought by diversity in the smaller size KDDAug+‡ is overwhelmed. Moreover, we only use KDDAug for SOTA comparison rather than KDDAug+ for two reasons: 1) The sample size of whole Daugextrasuperscriptsubscript𝐷augextraD_{\text{aug}}^{\text{extra}} is enormous. Thus, it is infeasible to directly train models with whole Daugextrasuperscriptsubscript𝐷augextraD_{\text{aug}}^{\text{extra}} (KDDAug+). 2) For efficiency and fair comparison with prior work SimpleAug [31], we controlled the number of samples to be the same as SimpleAug (i.e., KDDAug+‡ in Table 7 and 8).
